newsitem.title: CHINA: Chinese Premier Li Peng leaves for Russia.
newsitem.headline: Chinese Premier Li Peng leaves for Russia.

text.p: Chinese Premier Li Peng left on Thursday for a three-day visit to Russia that officials said marked the inauguration of a system of regular meetings between prime ministers of the neighbouring nuclear powers.
Diplomats said the main focus of Li's trip would be to boost economic links and pave the way for a presidential summit next year.

Li could become the first foreign leader to meet Yeltsin since the Russian president's return to work on Monday from heart surgery, setting the stage for a visit to Moscow by Chinese President and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin in 1997.
"The visit marks the formal inauguration of a regular meeting mechanism between the prime ministers of China and Russia," the official Xinhua news agency said.

Although politics will take a back seat on this visit, that official viewpoint underlined how much both China and Russia stand to gain in a delicate balancing act of their political ties with the West, analysts said.

Li is accompanied by Vice Premier Li Lanqing and Minister of the State Planning Commission Chen Jinhua as well several deputy ministers and officials in charge of China's nuclear and aviation industries -- sectors of great potential cooperation.
Officials of both sides have said economic ties have failed to keep pace with the rapid improvement in political links between the former rivals for world communist leadership.
Two-way trade was a modest $6.38 billion in the first nine months of this year, only a small portion of China's nearly $200 billion worth of trade over the same period.

State media said this week China and Russia were working on a plan to boost cross-border trade by setting up a special zone in the northeastern Chinese city of Suifenhe that would allow free movement for traders.
Trade between China and Russia through Suifenhe amounted to 2.1 billion yuan ($253.0 million) between January and August.
The two nations are also haggling over big-ticket items from nuclear power plants to a natural gas pipeline, and Li's visit may not yield a breakthrough, analysts said.
Russian officials in Beijing said there was still a wide gap between the two sides on a previously agreed on plan for China to buy Russian nuclear technology.
Beijing wants the multibillion dollar deal to use as little cash as possible while Moscow, badly in need of hard currency, is pushing for a more generous payment.

China has said it would switch the site of a nuclear plant using Russian technology in a move that is expected to make the project more commercially viable and ease some of the financial concerns, analysts said.
Russia is looking to make headway on a plan to build a pipeline to carry Siberian natural gas to China while it is also seeking a role in this country's huge Three Gorges dam project.
Officials and analysts said the visit would also have a political theme.
While the two sides need to foster their relations with the West they must also demonstrate some independence to strengthen their hand domestically and on the international stage.

The Russian government has come under pressure from its communist and nationalist opposition alike to abandon what is seen as a pro-Western stance and renew its ties with the former ally of the communist era.
Diplomats in Beijing said China had a similar interest in showing it had alternatives to the West, although it would use this lever cautiously.
